text: The tropical sun pokes its mighty head over the lush gree hills creating a peaceful early morning mist that falls o a beat-up soccer field and the crude dirt track that Surrounds it. A rooster's crowing breaks the eerie silence as a ghost l figure circles the track. This is no weekend jogger. This is: DERICE BANNOCK, Olymp hopeful and one of the island's top sprinters. Derice has face of an African Prince and the long fluid stride of a4 champion. ...That we use our governing power to disqualify them from competing in the 1988 Calgary Olympics. A murmur of acknowledgement rolls through the room. But o OFFICIAL speaks up.
But, on what grounds...They did everything that was asked of them.  89.
Oh, come now, gentlemen...There must be some shortcoming we've all overlocked. Some officials nod, some sit stoic. Some even go so far a smile.
All those who wish to show that they are in favor of disqualifying the Jamaican bobsled team may now do so with a show of hands. All nine hands go up.
CLOSE ON: Four hands holding up bottles of coke for a toa Pull back to reveal four ecstatic Jamaicans smiling ear t ear.

To following your dreams and never giving up no matter what. The boys howl their approval, clink their bottles togethe and drink. Sanka is so exuberant that he just can't help but dance. others watch and laugh. Sanka spots Irv at the door.
Hey, sled-god...Come on over and join the party!! Irv walks over to the guys. His posture is very serious. There is absolutely no joy in his body. Derice looks at I and knows something isn't right.
What's wrong? CLOSE ON: Irv. His face is a picture of doom.

Did they give you a reason why?

They say we haven't run in any official races Irv says it's just a bunch of B.S., but there's nothing we can do about it.
INT. MOMMA COFFIE'S —- NEXT DAY Joy stands at the bar on the telephone.
{into phone) I'm so sorry, sweetheart...I don't know what to say.

The office is empty except for a female SECRETARY behind desk. Irv comes barging through the door and goes right up to t secretary.  91.

Beautiful. Irv blasts past the secretary.
Sir...You're not allowed in there!
Kurt, Shindler, Kroychzeck and FOUR OTHER OFFICIALS we haven't seen before are sitting at a conference table whe Irv comes barging through the door.
Alright, Kurt...I want to talk to you. Shindler cuts Irv off
I'm sorry, Mr. Smuin. There's nothing te talk about.

But in an Olympic year the ‘Qualifiers’ count as a World Cup Series race.  92.
That may have been true in past Olympic years, but this year the federation has decided to change its policy.
(disbelief) Change its policy?! A GERMAN OFFICIAL chips in.
The federation has the right to do whatever they feel is in the best interest of the sport.
I thought making sure that the right teams end up in Calgary was in the best interest of the sport. A French official speaks up.
Our only concern isn't simply what makes for the best competition...We must also be concerned about the potential for embarrassment.
I didn't know four black guys ina bobsled could make you blush.
I think we've heard enough.
Excuse me, but I haven't finished with my appeal.
What appeal? Irv grabs a piece of paper off the table, spits on it, an slaps it back down,  93.

@ This appeal...Now, I did a lot to help this sport and I did a lot to hurt it...But I've paid for my mistakes and I've paid hard...That's gotta be worth at least a minute of your time. The board is silent...Irv continues. Beat.

Twenty years ago I won my first gold medal, and a lot of the people in this room said it was a fluke...that the Americans got lucky...Well, I think by now those of you who thought that would admit that you were wrong, and that when we broke the great European dynasty, it was the best thing that had ever happened to this sport...What if you had decided to keep us out of the Olympics?...What if you had said, "Oh, they're just a bunch of upstarts. They're no good for the r image of the sport.” Right at Kurt.

Where would you be, coach...if they had kept us out in '68?...You...who never lost your faith while everybody laughed and taunted us...You,..who did more than anybody to change the face of ‘bobsled- ding...I know I let you down, Kurt...I know I broke your heart in Saporro, but don't take it out on my guys. They're who we were twenty years ago...And it don't matter if they finish first or fiftieth... To all of them.  94.

...They deserve a chance to represent their country and march into that stadium...They deserve the the chance to wave their nation's flag...That's the greatest honor any athlete can ever have...And that's what the Olympics are all about. Kurt starts to shift in his seat. The committee sits sile Irv turns and heads for the door.

Our plane leaves in three hours...Let us know what you decide. INT. THE BOYS' HOTEL ROOM —- TWO AND A KALF HOURS LATER The bags are packed and by the door. The boys are dressed go home. They sit on their beds ringing their hands. Irv checks his watch as he paces like a caged panther. The boys look to each other, then to Irv. THE TENSION IS INSANE. THE PHONE RINGS. (no visible emotion) Hello...Uh huh...Uh huh...uUh huh...Alright, thank you. He hangs up the phone. The boys' eyes are on him, but Irv just stands there,
Well?! Irv raises one fist in the air. Sanka yelps with joy, Jun jumps on Yul and Derice is near tears as he silently than God.
THE GROUND moving close and fast. We HEAR a runner’s RHYTHMIC BREATHING.

I'm feeling very Olympic this afternoon. He and Derice give each other five.

{re: the radio announcer) This fool better watch his mouth.

‘Cause you keep runnin' into the toilet.

I will, and I'll forget your Ein Zvei Drein' Swiss wanna be ass with it.
Why shouldn't we wanna be like the Swiss ...They the best there is!
We ain't no Swiss. We Jamaicans...We can't be bitin’ nobody's style. We got our own style.
Kissin' eggs ain't no kind of style...This is the Olympics...This ain't no stupid push~cart derby! This cuts Sanka to the quick. Junior nods.

(honest) Hey, rasta...Let me tell you a little somethin'...I ain't come up here and freeze my ass off so you can whip me like an old mule ready for the grave...Truth be told, I just came to help you win your medal.

So am I...He told us to look deep inside...And when I look deep inside, I only see Jamaica.

Derice, mon, I known you since before Merlene Jefferies asked to see your ding a ling and I'm tellin' you as a friend...If we look Jamaican, walk Jamaican, talk Jamaican, and is Jamaican, then we sure as heli better bobsled Jamaican.

You're on the air.

Positive!

Breathin' fire!

Well, Bannock junior...Ready to follow in your father's footsteps?

You think so?

Then we'll bring you back a daggy- bac. Irv is about to close the door.

Shoot. Irv now comes into the room.
Remember the time you saw me talkin' with that Larry fellow?
What about it?
Well, he said a few things about you, and I was just wondering...
(interrupting) You want to know why I cheated in Saporro, right? Derice nods.

That's just what everybody told me, but it didn't make any difference "cause it wasn't what I felt inside.

I know what you mean...No matter how many races I won...No matter how many people believed in me...I've never felt okay inside...But that's alright, because I know that when I win that gold medal tomorrow I'm gonna feel okay all over...I'm finally gonna be able to look into that mirror and know that I'm enough.

Let me tell you something, son...A gold medal is a beautiful thing...But take it from me, if you're not enough without it...You'll never be enough with it. IRV PATS DERICE ON THE SHOULDER AND WALKS TO THE DOOR. At the door he turns.
See you at the finish line, kid.
